column2: CHAPTER XXIV.
column3: CHAPTER twenty four.

column2: NEXT day, towards night, we laid up under a little willow towhead out in the middle, where there was a village on each side of the river, and the duke and the king begun to lay out a plan for working them towns.
column3: NEXT day, towards night, we laid up under a little willow towhead out in the middle, where there was a village on each side of the river, and the duke and the king begun to lay out a plan for working them towns.

column2: Jim he spoke to the duke, and said he hoped it wouldn't take but a few hours, because it got mighty heavy and tiresome to him when he had to lay all day in the wigwam tied with the rope.
column3: Jim he spoke to the duke, and said he hoped it wouldn't take but a few hours, because it got mighty heavy and tiresome to him when he had to lay all day in the wigwam tied with the rope.

column2: You see, when we left him all alone we had to tie him, because if anybody happened on to him all by himself and not tied it wouldn't look much like he was a runaway nigger, you know.
column3: You see, when we left him all alone we had to tie him, because if anybody happened on to him all by himself and not tied it wouldn't look much like he was a runaway nigger, you know.

column2: So the duke said it _was_ kind of hard to have to lay roped all day, and he'd cipher out some way to get around it.
column3: So the duke said it underscore was underscore kind of hard to have to lay roped all day, and he'd cipher out some way to get around it.

column2: He was uncommon bright, the duke was, and he soon struck it.
column3: He was uncommon bright, the duke was, and he soon struck it.

column2: He dressed Jim up in King Lear's outfitit was a long curtain-calico gown, and a white horse-hair wig and whiskers; and then he took his theater paint and painted Jim's face and hands and ears and neck all over a dead, dull, solid blue, like a man that's been drownded nine days.
column3: He dressed Jim up in King Lear's outfit  it was a long curtain calico gown, and a white horse hair wig and whiskers; and then he took his theater paint and painted Jim's face and hands and ears and neck all over a dead, dull, solid blue, like a man that's been drownded nine days.

column2: Blamed if he warn't the horriblest looking outrage I ever see.
column3: Blamed if he warn't the horriblest looking outrage I ever see.

column2: Then the duke took and wrote out a sign on a shingle so:
column3: Then the duke took and wrote out a sign on a shingle so:

column2: Sick Arabbut harmless when not out of his head.
column3: Sick Arab  but harmless when not out of his head.

column2: And he nailed that shingle to a lath, and stood the lath up four or five foot in front of the wigwam.
column3: And he nailed that shingle to a lath, and stood the lath up four or five foot in front of the wigwam.

column2: Jim was satisfied.
column3: Jim was satisfied.

column2: He said it was a sight better than lying tied a couple of years every day, and trembling all over every time there was a sound.
column3: He said it was a sight better than lying tied a couple of years every day, and trembling all over every time there was a sound.

column2: The duke told him to make himself free and easy, and if anybody ever come meddling around, he must hop out of the wigwam, and carry on a little, and fetch a howl or two like a wild beast, and he reckoned they would light out and leave him alone. Which was sound enough judgment; but you take the average man, and he wouldn't wait for him to howl.
column3: The duke told him to make himself free and easy, and if anybody ever come meddling around, he must hop out of the wigwam, and carry on a little, and fetch a howl or two like a wild beast, and he reckoned they would light out and leave him alone. Which was sound enough judgment; but you take the average man, and he wouldn't wait for him to howl.

column2: Why, he didn't only look like he was dead, he looked considerable more than that.
column3: Why, he didn't only look like he was dead, he looked considerable more than that.

column2: These rapscallions wanted to try the Nonesuch again, because there was so much money in it, but they judged it wouldn't be safe, because maybe the news might a worked along down by this time.
column3: These rapscallions wanted to try the Nonesuch again, because there was so much money in it, but they judged it wouldn't be safe, because maybe the news might a worked along down by this time.

column2: They couldn't hit no project that suited exactly; so at last the duke said he reckoned he'd lay off and work his brains an hour or two and see if he couldn't put up something on the Arkansaw village; and the king he allowed he would drop over to t'other village without any plan, but just trust in Providence to lead him the profitable waymeaning the devil, I reckon.
column3: They couldn't hit no project that suited exactly; so at last the duke said he reckoned he'd lay off and work his brains an hour or two and see if he couldn't put up something on the Arkansaw village; and the king he allowed he would drop over to t'other village without any plan, but just trust in Providence to lead him the profitable way  meaning the devil, I reckon.

column2: We had all bought store clothes where we stopped last; and now the king put his'n on, and he told me to put mine on.
column3: We had all bought store clothes where we stopped last; and now the king put his'n on, and he told me to put mine on.

column2: I done it, of course.
column3: I done it, of course.

column2: The king's duds was all black, and he did look real swell and starchy.
column3: The king's duds was all black, and he did look real swell and starchy.

column2: I never knowed how clothes could change a body before.
column3: I never knowed how clothes could change a body before.

column2: Why, before, he looked like the orneriest old rip that ever was; but now, when he'd take off his new white beaver and make a bow and do a smile, he looked that grand and good and pious that you'd say he had walked right out of the ark, and maybe was old Leviticus himself.
column3: Why, before, he looked like the orneriest old rip that ever was; but now, when he'd take off his new white beaver and make a bow and do a smile, he looked that grand and good and pious that you'd say he had walked right out of the ark, and maybe was old leviticus himself.

column2: Jim cleaned up the canoe, and I got my paddle ready.
column3: Jim cleaned up the canoe, and I got my paddle ready.

column2: There was a big steamboat laying at the shore away up under the point, about three mile above the townbeen there a couple of hours, taking on freight.
column3: There was a big steamboat laying at the shore away up under the point, about three mile above the town  been there a couple of hours, taking on freight.

column2: Says the king:
column3: Says the king:

column2: Seein' how I'm dressed, I reckon maybe I better arrive down from St. Louis or Cincinnati, or some other big place.	Seein' how I'm dressed, I reckon maybe I better arrive down from saint Louis or Cincinnati, or some other big place.
column3: false

column2: Go for the steamboat, Huckleberry; we'll come down to the village on her."
column3: Go for the steamboat, Huckleberry; we'll come down to the village on her."

column2: I didn't have to be ordered twice to go and take a steamboat ride. I fetched the shore a half a mile above the village, and then went scooting along the bluff bank in the easy water.
column3: I didn't have to be ordered twice to go and take a steamboat ride. I fetched the shore a half a mile above the village, and then went scooting along the bluff bank in the easy water.

column2: Pretty soon we come to a nice innocent-looking young country jake setting on a log swabbing the sweat off of his face, for it was powerful warm weather; and he had a couple of big carpet-bags by him.
column3: Pretty soon we come to a nice innocent looking young country jake setting on a log swabbing the sweat off of his face, for it was powerful warm weather; and he had a couple of big carpet bags by him.

column2: Run her nose in shore, says the king.
column3: Run her nose in shore, says the king.

column2: I done it.
column3: I done it.

column2: Wher' you bound for, young man?
column3: Wher' you bound for, young man?

column2: For the steamboat; going to Orleans.
column3: For the steamboat; going to Orleans.

column2: Git aboard, says the king.
column3: Git aboard, says the king.

column2: Hold on a minute, my servant 'll he'p you with them bags.	Hold on a minute, my servant 'l l he'p you with them bags.
column3: false

column2: Jump out and he'p the gentleman, Adolphus"meaning me, I see.
column3: Jump out and he'p the gentleman, Adolphus"  meaning me, I see.

column2: I done so, and then we all three started on again.
column3: I done so, and then we all three started on again.

column2: The young chap was mighty thankful; said it was tough work toting his baggage such weather. He asked the king where he was going, and the king told him he'd come down the river and landed at the other village this morning, and now he was going up a few mile to see an old friend on a farm up there.
column3: The young chap was mighty thankful; said it was tough work toting his baggage such weather. He asked the king where he was going, and the king told him he'd come down the river and landed at the other village this morning, and now he was going up a few mile to see an old friend on a farm up there.

column2: The young fellow says:
column3: The young fellow says:

column2: When I first see you I says to myself, 'It's Mr. Wilks, sure, and he come mighty near getting here in time.' But then I says again, 'No, I reckon it ain't him, or else he wouldn't be paddling up the river.' You _ain't_ him, are you?
column3: When I first see you I says to myself, 'It's mr Wilks, sure, and he come mighty near getting here in time.' But then I says again, 'No, I reckon it ain't him, or else he wouldn't be paddling up the river.' You underscore ain't underscore him, are you?

column2: No, my name's BlodgettElexander Blodgett_Reverend_ Elexander Blodgett, I s'pose I must say, as I'm one o' the Lord's poor servants. But still I'm jist as able to be sorry for Mr. Wilks for not arriving in time, all the same, if he's missed anything by itwhich I hope he hasn't.
column3: No, my name's Blodgett  Elexander Blodgett underscore Reverend underscore Elexander Blodgett, I s'pose I must say, as I'm one o' the Lord's poor servants. But still I'm jist as able to be sorry for mr Wilks for not arriving in time, all the same, if he's missed anything by it  which I hope he hasn't.

column2: Well, he don't miss any property by it, because he'll get that all right; but he's missed seeing his brother Peter diewhich he mayn't mind, nobody can tell as to thatbut his brother would a give anything in this world to see _him_ before he died; never talked about nothing else all these three weeks; hadn't seen him since they was boys togetherand hadn't ever seen his brother William at allthat's the deef and dumb oneWilliam ain't more than thirty or thirty-five.	Well, he don't miss any property by it, because he'll get that all right; but he's missed seeing his brother peter die  which he mayn't mind, nobody can tell as to that  but his brother would a give anything in this world to see underscore him underscore before he died; never talked about nothing else all these three weeks; hadn't seen him since they was boys together  and hadn't ever seen his brother William at all  that's the deef and dumb one  William ain't more than thirty or thirty five.
column3: false

column2: Peter and George were the only ones that come out here; George was the married brother; him and his wife both died last year.
column3: peter and George were the only ones that come out here; George was the married brother; him and his wife both died last year.

column2: Harvey and William's the only ones that's left now; and, as I was saying, they haven't got here in time."
column3: Harvey and William's the only ones that's left now; and, as I was saying, they haven't got here in time."

column2: Did anybody send 'em word?
column3: Did anybody send 'em word?

column2: Oh, yes; a month or two ago, when Peter was first took; because Peter said then that he sorter felt like he warn't going to get well this time.	Oh, yes; a month or two ago, when peter was first took; because peter said then that he sorter felt like he warn't going to get well this time.
column3: false

column2: You see, he was pretty old, and George's g'yirls was too young to be much company for him, except Mary Jane, the red-headed one; and so he was kinder lonesome after George and his wife died, and didn't seem to care much to live.
column3: You see, he was pretty old, and George's g'yirls was too young to be much company for him, except Mary Jane, the red headed one; and so he was kinder lonesome after George and his wife died, and didn't seem to care much to live.

column2: He most desperately wanted to see Harveyand William, too, for that matterbecause he was one of them kind that can't bear to make a will.
column3: He most desperately wanted to see Harvey  and William, too, for that matter  because he was one of them kind that can't bear to make a will.

column2: He left a letter behind for Harvey, and said he'd told in it where his money was hid, and how he wanted the rest of the property divided up so George's g'yirls would be all rightfor George didn't leave nothing.
column3: He left a letter behind for Harvey, and said he'd told in it where his money was hid, and how he wanted the rest of the property divided up so George's g'yirls would be all right  for George didn't leave nothing.

column2: And that letter was all they could get him to put a pen to."
column3: And that letter was all they could get him to put a pen to."

column2: Why do you reckon Harvey don't come?	Why do you reckon Harvey don't come?
column3: false

column2: Wher' does he live?"
column3: Wher' does he live?"

column2: Oh, he lives in EnglandSheffieldpreaches therehasn't ever been in this country.	Oh, he lives in England  Sheffield  preaches there  hasn't ever been in this country.
column3: true

column2: He hasn't had any too much timeand besides he mightn't a got the letter at all, you know."
column3: He hasn't had any too much time  and besides he mightn't a got the letter at all, you know."

column2: Too bad, too bad he couldn't a lived to see his brothers, poor soul. You going to Orleans, you say?
column3: Too bad, too bad he couldn't a lived to see his brothers, poor soul. You going to Orleans, you say?

column2: Yes, but that ain't only a part of it.	Yes, but that ain't only a part of it.
column3: true

column2: I'm going in a ship, next Wednesday, for Ryo Janeero, where my uncle lives."
column3: I'm going in a ship, next Wednesday, for Ryo Janeero, where my uncle lives."

column2: It's a pretty long journey.	It's a pretty long journey.
column3: true

column2: But it'll be lovely; wisht I was a-going. Is Mary Jane the oldest?
column3: But it'll be lovely; wisht I was a going. Is Mary Jane the oldest?

column2: How old is the others?"
column3: How old is the others?"

column2: Mary Jane's nineteen, Susan's fifteen, and Joanna's about fourteenthat's the one that gives herself to good works and has a hare-lip.
column3: Mary Jane's nineteen, Susan's fifteen, and Joanna's about fourteen  that's the one that gives herself to good works and has a hare lip.

column2: Poor things! to be left alone in the cold world so.
column3: Poor things! to be left alone in the cold world so.

column2: Well, they could be worse off.	Well, they could be worse off.
column3: true

column2: Old Peter had friends, and they ain't going to let them come to no harm.
column3: Old peter had friends, and they ain't going to let them come to no harm.

column2: There's Hobson, the Babtis' preacher; and Deacon Lot Hovey, and Ben Rucker, and Abner Shackleford, and Levi Bell, the lawyer; and Dr. Robinson, and their wives, and the widow Bartley, andwell, there's a lot of them; but these are the ones that Peter was thickest with, and used to write about sometimes, when he wrote home; so Harvey 'll know where to look for friends when he gets here."
column3: There's Hobson, the Babtis' preacher; and Deacon Lot Hovey, and Ben Rucker, and Abner Shackleford, and Levi Bell, the lawyer; and dr Robinson, and their wives, and the widow Bartley, and  well, there's a lot of them; but these are the ones that peter was thickest with, and used to write about sometimes, when he wrote home; so Harvey 'l l know where to look for friends when he gets here."

column2: Well, the old man went on asking questions till he just fairly emptied that young fellow.
column3: Well, the old man went on asking questions till he just fairly emptied that young fellow.

column2: Blamed if he didn't inquire about everybody and everything in that blessed town, and all about the Wilkses; and about Peter's businesswhich was a tanner; and about George'swhich was a carpenter; and about Harvey'swhich was a dissentering minister; and so on, and so on.
column3: Blamed if he didn't inquire about everybody and everything in that blessed town, and all about the Wilkses; and about Peter's business  which was a tanner; and about George's  which was a carpenter; and about Harvey's  which was a dissentering minister; and so on, and so on.

column2: Then he says:
column3: Then he says:

column2: What did you want to walk all the way up to the steamboat for?
column3: What did you want to walk all the way up to the steamboat for?

column2: Because she's a big Orleans boat, and I was afeard she mightn't stop there.	Because she's a big Orleans boat, and I was afeard she mightn't stop there.
column3: true

column2: When they're deep they won't stop for a hail.
column3: When they're deep they won't stop for a hail.

column2: A Cincinnati boat will, but this is a St. Louis one."
column3: A Cincinnati boat will, but this is a saint Louis one."

column2: Was Peter Wilks well off?
column3: Was peter Wilks well off?

column2: Oh, yes, pretty well off.	Oh, yes, pretty well off.
column3: true

column2: He had houses and land, and it's reckoned he left three or four thousand in cash hid up som'ers."
column3: He had houses and land, and it's reckoned he left three or four thousand in cash hid up som'ers."

column2: When did you say he died?
column3: When did you say he died?

column2: I didn't say, but it was last night.
column3: I didn't say, but it was last night.

column2: Funeral to-morrow, likely?
column3: Funeral to morrow, likely?

column2: Yes, 'bout the middle of the day.
column3: Yes, 'bout the middle of the day.

column2: Well, it's all terrible sad; but we've all got to go, one time or another.	Well, it's all terrible sad; but we've all got to go, one time or another.
column3: true

column2: So what we want to do is to be prepared; then we're all right."
column3: So what we want to do is to be prepared; then we're all right."

column2: Yes, sir, it's the best way.	Yes, sir, it's the best way.
column3: true

column2: Ma used to always say that."
column3: Ma used to always say that."

column2: When we struck the boat she was about done loading, and pretty soon she got off.
column3: When we struck the boat she was about done loading, and pretty soon she got off.

column2: The king never said nothing about going aboard, so I lost my ride, after all.
column3: The king never said nothing about going aboard, so I lost my ride, after all.

column2: When the boat was gone the king made me paddle up another mile to a lonesome place, and then he got ashore and says:
column3: When the boat was gone the king made me paddle up another mile to a lonesome place, and then he got ashore and says:

column2: Now hustle back, right off, and fetch the duke up here, and the new carpet-bags.	Now hustle back, right off, and fetch the duke up here, and the new carpet bags.
column3: true

column2: And if he's gone over to t'other side, go over there and git him.
column3: And if he's gone over to t'other side, go over there and git him.

column2: And tell him to git himself up regardless.
column3: And tell him to git himself up regardless.

column2: Shove along, now."
column3: Shove along, now."

column2: I see what _he_ was up to; but I never said nothing, of course.
column3: I see what underscore he underscore was up to; but I never said nothing, of course.

column2: When I got back with the duke we hid the canoe, and then they set down on a log, and the king told him everything, just like the young fellow had said itevery last word of it.
column3: When I got back with the duke we hid the canoe, and then they set down on a log, and the king told him everything, just like the young fellow had said it  every last word of it.

column2: And all the time he was a-doing it he tried to talk like an Englishman; and he done it pretty well, too, for a slouch.
column3: And all the time he was a doing it he tried to talk like an Englishman; and he done it pretty well, too, for a slouch.

column2: I can't imitate him, and so I ain't a-going to try to; but he really done it pretty good.
column3: I can't imitate him, and so I ain't a going to try to; but he really done it pretty good.

column2: Then he says:
column3: Then he says:

column2: How are you on the deef and dumb, Bilgewater?
column3: How are you on the deef and dumb, Bilgewater?

column2: The duke said, leave him alone for that; said he had played a deef and dumb person on the histronic boards.
column3: The duke said, leave him alone for that; said he had played a deef and dumb person on the histronic boards.

column2: So then they waited for a steamboat.
column3: So then they waited for a steamboat.

column2: About the middle of the afternoon a couple of little boats come along, but they didn't come from high enough up the river; but at last there was a big one, and they hailed her.
column3: About the middle of the afternoon a couple of little boats come along, but they didn't come from high enough up the river; but at last there was a big one, and they hailed her.

column2: She sent out her yawl, and we went aboard, and she was from Cincinnati; and when they found we only wanted to go four or five mile they was booming mad, and gave us a cussing, and said they wouldn't land us.
column3: She sent out her yawl, and we went aboard, and she was from Cincinnati; and when they found we only wanted to go four or five mile they was booming mad, and gave us a cussing, and said they wouldn't land us.

column2: But the king was ca'm.
column3: But the king was ca'm.

column2: He says:
column3: He says:

column2: If gentlemen kin afford to pay a dollar a mile apiece to be took on and put off in a yawl, a steamboat kin afford to carry 'em, can't it?
column3: If gentlemen kin afford to pay a dollar a mile apiece to be took on and put off in a yawl, a steamboat kin afford to carry 'em, can't it?

column2: So they softened down and said it was all right; and when we got to the village they yawled us ashore.
column3: So they softened down and said it was all right; and when we got to the village they yawled us ashore.

column2: About two dozen men flocked down when they see the yawl a-coming, and when the king says:
column3: About two dozen men flocked down when they see the yawl a coming, and when the king says:

column2: Kin any of you gentlemen tell me wher' Mr. Peter Wilks lives? they give a glance at one another, and nodded their heads, as much as to say, "What d' I tell you?" Then one of them says, kind of soft and gentle:
column3: Kin any of you gentlemen tell me where' mr peter Wilks lives? they give a glance at one another, and nodded their heads, as much as to say, "What d' I tell you?" Then one of them says, kind of soft and gentle:

column2: I'm sorry sir, but the best we can do is to tell you where he _did_ live yesterday evening.
column3: I'm sorry sir, but the best we can do is to tell you where he underscore did underscore live yesterday evening.

column2: Sudden as winking the ornery old cretur went an to smash, and fell up against the man, and put his chin on his shoulder, and cried down his back, and says:
column3: Sudden as winking the ornery old cretur went an to smash, and fell up against the man, and put his chin on his shoulder, and cried down his back, and says:

column2: Alas, alas, our poor brothergone, and we never got to see him; oh, it's too, too hard!
column3: Alas, alas, our poor brother  gone, and we never got to see him; oh, it's too, too hard!

column2: Then he turns around, blubbering, and makes a lot of idiotic signs to the duke on his hands, and blamed if he didn't drop a carpet-bag and bust out a-crying.
column3: Then he turns around, blubbering, and makes a lot of idiotic signs to the duke on his hands, and blamed if he didn't drop a carpet bag and bust out a crying.

column2: If they warn't the beatenest lot, them two frauds, that ever I struck.
column3: If they warn't the beatenest lot, them two frauds, that ever I struck.

column2: Well, the men gathered around and sympathized with them, and said all sorts of kind things to them, and carried their carpet-bags up the hill for them, and let them lean on them and cry, and told the king all about his brother's last moments, and the king he told it all over again on his hands to the duke, and both of them took on about that dead tanner like they'd lost the twelve disciples.
column3: Well, the men gathered around and sympathized with them, and said all sorts of kind things to them, and carried their carpet bags up the hill for them, and let them lean on them and cry, and told the king all about his brother's last moments, and the king he told it all over again on his hands to the duke, and both of them took on about that dead tanner like they'd lost the twelve disciples.

column2: Well, if ever I struck anything like it, I'm a nigger.
column3: Well, if ever I struck anything like it, I'm a nigger.

column2: It was enough to make a body ashamed of the human race.
column3: It was enough to make a body ashamed of the human race.

column2: CHAPTER XXV.
column3: CHAPTER twenty five.

column2: THE news was all over town in two minutes, and you could see the people tearing down on the run from every which way, some of them putting on their coats as they come.
column3: THE news was all over town in two minutes, and you could see the people tearing down on the run from every which way, some of them putting on their coats as they come.

column2: Pretty soon we was in the middle of a crowd, and the noise of the tramping was like a soldier march.
column3: Pretty soon we was in the middle of a crowd, and the noise of the tramping was like a soldier march.

column2: The windows and dooryards was full; and every minute somebody would say, over a fence:
column3: The windows and dooryards was full; and every minute somebody would say, over a fence:
